reviewText: What a sad, sad film.  The Stepford Wives only proves that big stars and a big name director like Frank Oz do not always make good pictures.  There was nothing worth saving from this movie.  From the opening scenes to the final credits, and all that I found lying in-between was pure gibberish.  It is annoying to find a film with such decent actors to be so horribly bad.  Kidman has been working very hard lately to make a name for herself in the Hollywood community that a film like this could debunk her.  From the story, to the poorly mismatched characters, to the cheap CGI, this film smelled of recycled garbage from the opening.  It should have been returned, but instead I forged ahead and watched.As bad as this film was, there was a glimmer of light at the beginning.  Kidman's character is somewhat humorous as the television executive with ideas on how to make women more powerful on screen.  What she shows her shareholders are tiny morsels of comedy, but those are quickly eaten nothing is left behind except for crumbs.  From the moment that she leaves the podium, her role is over.  Kidman tries to capture the essence of her character, but just cannot.  I have trouble-seeing Kidman as a comic actress, especially when she has mastered the drama/thriller/musical genre so well.  The lack of comfortability with her character is ultimately what flaws Kidman's performance from the start.  You just never see her excitement or comfort level in her eyes.  You never saw her true character.  This goes the same with everyone else in this film.  Broderick was the worst decision as her husband.  They had no chemistry, no love, and no passion.  I saw them as two actors with lines instead of a secure relationship.  Couple this with more horrible performances by Midler (who never quite reaches the high of her character), Glenn Close (who seemed like she was over-the-top with her character and just finally happy to be in a film with some big name stars), Lovitz (what was he doing in this movie?), and even the always loveable Walken (who seemed stale and sterile throughout the entire film) just flopped.  The actors and their inability to carry this film to a higher level was only half the issue with this film, the other problem lied in the hands of director Frank Oz.What was he thinking in this film?  It felt like his children got into the editing room and spilled glue on the cut film and that was the way he edited it.  There was no continuity at all.  We would jump from one location to the next and then further again without any warning or care.  This creates a sense of distraction and unease in the tone of the film.  Secondly, did Oz know what this film was about?  At one point I thought that these women were robots, and the next they are humans with computer chips in their minds.  What about the sparks?  What about the ATM?  This never seemed to fit at all.  It was as if Oz had made two films and spliced the beginning of one and the end of the other together.First time filmmakers could have done a better job than Frank Oz on this film.  I needed this to be a very dark comedy (if even a comedy at all).  Where was the darkness in this film?  I will tell you ... THERE WASN'T ANY!  If there was anything at all in this film, I would give credit, but there has been nothing redeemable about this film at all.  The choppy direction that Oz perfects jumbles the themes and tones to nearly nothing.  I could not honestly sit here and tell you what the tone of the film was.  I think it was locked somewhere in Oz's mind, and it couldn't get out.  This goes the same with the theme of the film.  Does it have something to do with perfection or feminism?  A happy home or being wealthy?  Maybe it has to do with cooking cup cakes over pies?  How about playing God in suburbia?  Who knows?  I couldn't tell, and I am definitely not willing to watch it again to find out.Overall, this was the worst film that I have seen this year by far.  The ending was laughable and just plain stupid, as you could probably say the same for the rest of the film.  All the actors did the worst jobs they could and it became increasingly obvious that Oz should just go back to doing Muppet voices.  There is nothing of value in this movie and if you chose to spend the money to see it than at least you have been warned.  This is yet another perfect example of a Hollywood blunder.  Where was the Inspector Gadget music when you needed it?  BLAH!Grade: * out of *****

reviewText: If you don't want to be spoiled about the movie, maybe you should stop reading my review now...As it's own movie, it wasn't that bad... until the end. It was a pretty funny movie, oddly enough, since the original had more of a horror movie feel to it. Not overly witty comedy, but there were parts that deserved at least a chuckle. In the original, I don't think they had a freakin' pet at all, nonetheless, a mechanic one. The plot of the two movies are similar, but they are by far totally different also. The original was more of a horror movie approach at the look of how women were viewed in society. You know what I mean. You have the main character who is all 'Feminism girl power' who ends up in the town of Stepford and finds out all the women are being replaced with robots to be the perfect housewives. The original made a statement, whether you cared or not. The remake here, on the other hand, had no statement. It was just about a spoiled fairly well off woman who loses her job so her and her family move to the suburbs in the seemingly perfect town of Stepford. A similarity is the women in the town are perfect in every way. But in the first, the women were replaced with robots. In the remake, they simply have chips embedded into their brains. Now, the bad part of the movie is the end. When the main character, played by Nicole Kidman, finds out the secret of the Men's Association, she's standing in a whole room full of men, including her husband, while she's trapped, waiting for him to decide whether he wants to switch her to a perfect wife or not. Of course the movie ends with the two tricking the rest of the members of the Men's Association, and her husband confessing that he didn't change her, because he couldn't go through with it. Nicole Kidman and Matthew Broderick give each other a loving look as she tells him that what he did made him a real man. The first thought that crossed my mind was, 'Nevermind the fact that he was contemplating replacing you to begin with.' I won't reveal the actual bad guy of the movie, but it's not who you think, and when you find out who it is, you'll find the ending just as dumb as I did.

reviewText: I actually had no intention of seeing this movie but have to admit to being succesfully goaded by some nifty trailer advertising. Yet another remake is put through the mill here, but somehow you just know that with Frank Oz directing, there is unlikely to be any of the dark or sinister tension of the original movie. If you don't know the story, Kidman and Broderick play not so happy couple who move to the "burbs" of Connecticut after her high powered career is pushed off the rails. Broderick enrolls in the "Mens Club" and is in awe of all of his new found friends who seem fully content, and have happy smiling wives who bend to their every whim. Stepford seems the ideal community, too ideal in fact, and Kidman and Bette Midler (playing a neurotic author)suspect foul play, and in so doing hopefully pull us (the audience) into a darkly comic mystery? Or not as the case may be as this can only be regarded as a limp comedy at best. This movie has a great cast, and the first 30 minutes or so builds nicely and promises much. Oz directing tries to bring a contemporary slant with some subtle side comment on reality shows, but the reworking of the original script gets quickly bogged down in its own incredulity. Some reviews have been a little too harsh in my opinion, probably due mostly to the inevitability of it all (even if you haven't seen the original) coupled with a completely ridiculous ending that's too silly for words. But despite this there are a few saving graces, particularly from Roger Bart as the overly camp Roger Bannister who aids Midler and Kidman. Overall though, a very disappointing outing considering the array of talent on display. Check it out for a few laughs if you must, and then compare it the original, which although outdated is far superior. 2 stars (just) mainly for cast. Enjoy?

reviewText: Ira Levin's cautionary novel, "The Stepford Wives", was a fascinating fable of the ultimate male backlash to feminism; in 1975, director Bryan Forbes turned the novel into a chilling variation of "Invasion of the Body Snatchers", as innocent wives are substituted by zombie-like robots, their husbands bonding in a smugly evil male cult. Unsettling and ambiguous, the fate of the actual women is left to the viewer's imagination, making it far more frightening than a pat resolution would have been.This concept was apparently lost on Paramount, DreamWorks, and Frank Oz, who wavered between camp and black comedy heavy-handedness, in this 2004 remake. Scripted by Paul Rudnick, the women are no longer normal, sympathetic wives, but high-powered execs, with apparent agendas against men, and husbands little more than doorstops. Their fate, to become blond-haired sex-slave bimbos locked in 'June Cleever' mode, while their idiot spouses adjust their breast sizes by remote control, and swap the wives for favors, demeans both men and women, and even offers an out-of-place jab at homosexuals, as a funny gay spouse is turned into a right-wing religious zealot politician (how an openly gay couple would ever be even allowed in this community is ignored).While spoofing the earlier film isn't, in itself, a bad idea, no one involved in this project apparently had a clear vision of what they were aiming at, so continuity and logic are sadly missing. As other critics have rightly noted, the status of the wives waivers between being robots and being micro-chipped and brainwashed humans, making the Nicole Kidman 'template' body, and finale 'revelation' of community leader Christopher Walken's actual status as ridiculous as an ATM-spewing wife, and remote controls to adjust emotional responses and breast sizes, labeled, conveniently, with each wife's name. All the pretty, golden-hued settings, and Matthew Broderick's emergence as a 'good guy with a heart' who saves the day can't compensate for the quagmire of a plot.The real shame of it all is that the potential for a good film hovers over the proceedings, just out of reach, and some really fine performances are all for naught. Glenn Close gives a strangely sympathetic twist to the film's villain, Walken is the most engaging (and youthful) he's been in years, Bette Midler and Roger Bart are both hilarious, Jon Lovitz is at his silly best, and Nicole Kidman again proves herself more than adept at comedy, and portraying American women. Matthew Broderick seems to be making a career of playing milquetoast males (Ferris Bueller, where are you?), and for 'eye and ear candy', nothing can quite match Country Music sex symbol Faith Hill's orgasmic moans, and cup-size changes. All this, lost in a truly misguided film.What a waste!

reviewText: This movie is the height of incompetence, offering little more than minimal entertainment value. And unfortunately, it doesn't fall into the "so bad it's good" category, which would at least partially redeem it. It does serve, however, as a perfect example of the creative bankruptcy of today's Hollywood, where concept rules (let's remake "The Stepford Wives" as a comedy with Nicole Kidman!) and follow through is an afterthought.The blame has to be put right at the doors of the director, Frank Oz, and the writer, Paul Rudnick. The latter probably deserves most of the credit for this debacle: At his best, he's the king (or queen, in this case) of the one-liner, but no more than that -- character development is beyond his capabilities. At his worst (as in this movie), his one-liners lack wit and fall flat, and there's no real plot holding them together.Pity the poor actors assigned to this disaster. In her initial  scenes, Kidman proves to be a brilliant physical comedian -- in both her facial and body movements, she captures a perfect comic tone. Unfortunately, that doesn't last (the director's fault, I'd say), and she plays the rest of the movie like a serious drama, which doesn't work. Matthew Broderick gives one of his worst performances ever; he seems quite embarrassed to be in this turkey. Bette Midler does her best, but she's totally wasted, as it must be said, she often is in movies.The only one who captures the right tone and squeezes every laugh out of her lines is Glenn Close, who looks amazingly like a younger Cloris Leachman in this movie. She deserves a special Academy Award for bravery. Under loose directors (see Robert Altman's "Cookie's Fortune" -- or better yet, don't), she can sometimes go so far over the top as to be unfunny. But she's got her dial turned to just the right level this time. However, it's not nearly enough to save the movie.(SPOILER ALERT) Most insulting to the audience are this movie's wild inconsistencies. For example, we see Kidman and Broderick's kids at the beginning and then they're forgotten after that -- if it weren't for a couple of stray references to them in subsequent scenes, you'd assume this couple was childless. But most astounding of all is how the movie can't even be consistent in its central premise -- that is, what is occurring with the wives. The script can't decide if they're being killed and replaced by robots with special features (several scenes indicate that's the case), or if the women have simply received implants in the brain (as the ending indicates). I understand there were major reshoots done to try to fix this movie, but they seem to have only made things worse. If you can't even get your central conceit straight -- upon which your whole movie hangs -- then you have no right to be writing or directing a movie, much less a big-budget one.

reviewText: Either my tastes in film are far removed from the average movie-goer, or I'm in a mental institution, strapped to a bed, and loaded up with Haldol!I enjoyed this film quite a bit. It's not the greatest film I've ever seen. Nor is it the best film of the year. But what it IS is a highly enjoyable movie that makes you laugh at its predecessor in a not-unkindly-way. The original Stepford Wives was meant to be creepy and a bit campy (You can admit it! It was just a tad bit campy!). This film, in contrast, is made for visual enjoyment and comedic value. And the story isn't THAT far removed from the original's plot.This time, we have a young, powerful couple (played by Nicole Kidman and Matthew Broderick) who decide to make a life-change by moving to the quiet and tranquil city of Stepford, Conneticut. Everything seems perfect (especially the women!). But Nicole Kidman begins to notice something very odd about the Stepford Wives. They're a bit too...uh...cheery? Contrived? Controlled! Will her husband fall prey to the same ideals that made the other men of Stepford turn their wives into Betty Crocker Zombies?With an ensemble cast (including the outlandish Glen Close, Bette Midler, Faith Hill, and, of course, Christopher Walken), it's hard to say that this was a "bad" film. True, actors don't make the movie -- there's much more to film making than that -- but these talented film stars must have read the screenplay before signing on, wouldn't you agree?So WHY did I enjoy it so much? Simple. It made me laugh, and much of the film was pure eye-candy. The colorful dresses, the amazing set decorations, the haunting music accompaniments, and the inarguable fact that the director (Frank Oz) put his actors and actresses into freaky/funny roles (both at the same time) made for a wonderful movie-going spectacle. Bad movie? No way!

reviewText: I'm surprised by the comments made about this film. So few people got the joke. Granted, it's not a great film. It'll never land on any "Top 100" lists (at least not the ones that are complimentary anyway) but it's a lot better than what it's being given credit for.The acting in the film is very good. Nicole Kidman plays a stressed-to-the-hilt executive with personality quirks that include workaholism, chronic overachieving and a pathological need for control. Her performance is excellent. With her statuesque good looks she's every underachiever's dream babe (or notion of the perfect Dominatrix-take your pick). Matthew Broderick makes a great foil in the role of her husband. He's entirely convincing as a well and truly henpecked every-man who (finally) finds his "inner man". Bette Midler comes up with the type of textbook neurotic character that only she can come up with. Christopher Walken is perfect as a suave (but completely mad) scientist. Glenn Close manages a "permanent press" demeanour that could only exist on an automated product. Roger Bart is hilarious as a flamboyant gay man turned subdued Republican. Jon Lovitz isn't really called on to show much depth but he does get some great lines. He delivers them as only he can.There is a problem with the cohesion of the story line. One scene makes it seem as if robots have replaced the women; the physical aspects shown couldn't be managed by anything but a machine. Later situations show the ladies to be human, but changed. Somebody took a right instead of a left and forgot to change the signpost maybe? That scene should have been changed in favour of one that didn't puncture the plot.It's not a big problem though and it's quickly forgotten when watching the film. This version of "The Stepford Wives" isn't an imitation of the original film and it doesn't follow the novel literally either. It pokes fun at both and does so with a lot of affection. In the bigger picture it satirizes the fact that people are always trying to change each other. The town of Stepford and the automated shells that end up running around in wives clothing are part of the inevitable result of forcing personal change down a peoples' throats. It's only part of the result though. It's made clear that (at some point) "the men are next". The point the film makes is that doing that robs people of their individuality and eventually reduces them to a state where they may as well be robots. The creators took the idea and had some fun with it.The whole film has its tongue so far in its cheek that it's licking its ear from the inside. Everything about it is "over-the-top". Characterizations are played to extremes. The programmed-for-perfection wives are so flat they could be paper dolls. The "real women" at the other end of the spectrum are so neurotic they belong in rubber rooms. Their mates are such wimps they give new meaning to the term. The town itself represents an ideal that could never exist. It's delightfully absurd and had me laughing because of it.But it's best to watch it with a black jester's cap on.
summary: This Shouldn't be Taken So Seriously

reviewText: Frank Oz's eagerly awaited comedy/thriller remake of THE STEPFORD WIVES turned out to be a great big fizzer when it was released in the summer of 2004.  Whilst it does pale in comparison to the earlier 1975 Bryan Forbes film (based on the controversial Ira Levin novel), I believe that the remake of STEPFORD WIVES still has the ability to stir debate and argument about the delicate balance of power in married relationships.When hard-driven TV executive Joanna Eberhart (Nicole Kidman in a most unattractive brunette dutch-boy haircut) is fired from her job following the deadly aftermath of one of her television projects, husband Walter (Matthew Broderick) arranges for the family to relocate to the small Connecticut gated community of Stepford.There, Joanna's very principals are undermined as she finds herself in a world of perfect picket fences, Barbie doll-beautiful women and their very ordinary husbands.  When Joanna and Walter finally discover the horrific secret behind Stepford's glossy facade, will it be too late?  THE STEPFORD WIVES, even in this watered-down comedy version, still asks the potent question of how successful is a wife 'allowed' to be until she begins threatening her husband's masculinity.Bette Midler and Roger Bart add the bulk of the comedy with their supporting roles as two more cynical Stepford residents trying to rail against the system; and as always Glenn Close is a scene-stealing marvel as Stepford's resident grande dame (a kooky performance I love to refer to as "June Cleaver on smack")!  Nicole Kidman never does comedy especially well but has a charming presence, and Matthew Broderick is always great playing the nerdy nebbish.  Recommended.

reviewText: The original Stepford Wives was a barbed commentary on the kind of women men wanted, obedient, complacent, and seeing themselves as ranking lower than men.  It was a shot in the arm of the women's lib movement.  Fast forward nearly thirty years later.  The concept here is the same, but this version plays up the comedic side rather than the suspense and horror of the original.  It also shows that men don't have the monopoly on denigrating the opposite sex, given the male-bashing "Balance of Sex" and reality TV shows, "I Could Do Better" promoted by cutthroat network executive Joanna Eberhardt at the beginning.From there, the story remains the same, how she and her family go to Stepford, Connecticut.  Instantly, the sight of smiling buxom blonde women in nice summer dresses turn her husband Walter's head.  The smart house is in keeping with the high tech age, with even a cute electronic terrier to boot.Joanna isn't exactly chuffed with the brainless women, led by the bubby ever-smiling Claire Wellington.  Their idea of discussing a book for reading is not the latest volume of LBJ's biography, but a book of Christmas holiday ornaments.  She tries to fit in, ditching her darker coloured outfits and dressing up so that the one non-Stepford resembling wife, Bobbie Markowitz, a sardonic feminist author, says she looks like Betty Crocker.  Bobbie's kitchen looks like a tornado has visited, as she's way too busy with her latest book.Her first suspicions that things aren't what they are comes when a woman starts spinning like a top during a square dance, collapses, and emits sparks.  Joanna tries to offer assistance, and advises calling an ambulance, but everyone there is relying on Claire's wife Mike.The one big difference here is the presence of a gay couple, and the more feminine one, Roger, who is upbeat and flamboyant becomes the other person sympathetic to Joanna.  There is a clear separation of sexes, where the men hang out at the Men's Association, playing cards, drinking beer, and having fun with electronic toys.  Walter's a bit bewildered at the sight of the Stepford ATM, but when he comments deadpan "she gives out singles," all the men laugh good-naturedly.Nicole Kidman does competently as Joanna, but she is overshadowed by Bette Midler's Bobbie and Roger Bart's Roger.  Matthew Broderick (Walter) is good, but Glenn Close has seen better days.  Her makeup is pallid, pasty, with that artificial smile, making her another gargoyle-like character (q.v. Cruella de Vil).  And Christopher Walken (Mike) is just retreading the same villain role as before.Who knows what the decision was to cast pop-country singer Faith Hill as Sarah Saunderson, but given her image makeover as a haystack honey beginning with her Faith album, casting her as a Stepford Wife is ideal.  She does have some funny moments but at her expense.  No, she doesn't sing, but if that's her vocals in an offscreen bedroom scene, it shows she's got some kind of talent--some would call it talent.Like Diabolique and Abre Los Ojos, if you've seen the original...  The mystery is essentially the same, except updated for the high tech age, plus the ending is different.  All I'll say is that it ultimately reveals how some kind of give and take is needed between couples so both are able to reach their potentials.  In other words, a woman should not go to the extreme of being a brainless Stepford wife, but also not to the aggressive man-squashing pole either.  And the epithet "I Could Do Better" applies to both sexes, but in how both could treat each other with respect so that they are both validated as nice and intelligent human beings.  Yes, both could do better.  As for the movie, directed by Frank Oz (The Dark Crystal, Yoda's puppeteer), he has done all right.
summary: Men and women could all do better

reviewText: The ending here is beyond redemption, but otherwise this remake of the 1975 film from the novel by Ira Levin is not (entirely) bad.  It's a different sort of film than the original and probably would amuse (if not offend) Ira Levin if he were alive today.  But to put it bluntly, the film is a sellout to politically correct mentalities and could quite easily be called "Revenge of the Stepford Wives."  (Actually there was a TV movie from 1980 by that name that I haven't seen.)The original Stepford Wives starred Katharine Ross and Paula Prentiss and was a dark science fiction satire with only a few chuckles and a decidedly dark ending.  This film is played mostly for laughs and is full of all sorts of silly (shall I say stupid?) updates, like having a gay couple instead of a black couple and making the wives (prior to their coming to Stepford) very accomplished--CEOs, scientists, etc., while the husbands are Neanderthal nerds.  Nicole Kidman's Joanna Eberhart was a top TV exec while her husband Walter Kresby (played sheepishly by Matthew Broderick--note that Joanna did not take his last name) is a kind of ordinary joe and caddy to his wife.But what about the premise?  Let's be honest guys.  Wouldn't it be wonderful if our wives were totally devoted to our comfort and pleasure?  If they obeyed us and always kept the house and themselves spotless and catered to our every whim?  If they didn't get moody and were always rational, etc.?  Isn't it the natural state of the human male to be king of his castle and to have dominion over all he surveys?Well, at any rate here's an update on the Stepford Wives for the new millennium, an expansion of the concept, if you will.  Every man has not only a totally devoted and loving wife, but a totally devoted and loving mistress (or two).  They would be robots of course, manufactured as consumer goods by General Electric, Microsoft and Intel.  But here is the zinger: every woman would have a slavishly devoted husband and secret lover, etc.  And while we are at it, they would have loving, appreciative and accomplished robotic children.  In other words, nobody would actually interact with other living, breathing human beings.  How crude, how disgusting.  Instead all humans would interact only with perfect robots perfectly designed to make their world a heaven on earth.Or, more likely we would just be hooked up to an elaborate software program with an utterly convincing virtual reality in which we would have a loyal and loving spouse, two extracurricular lovers..., etc.Fly in the ointment?I think it would be called boredom.Bottom line on this film: a few laughs, a good cast wasted, but a nice documentation of filmland executive stupidity.

reviewText: Look, it's a comedy!  No, it's a thriller!  No, it's a sci-fi film!  No, it's a horror film!  Wait, what the heck IS it?  Frank Oz's 2004 "The Stepford Wives" remake of the 1975 original, which was based on the book by Ira Levin, suffers from a major identity problem.  The film itself doesn't seem to know what its message is and is annoyingly scatterbrained, throwing around different plot elements from the genres mentioned above with no real center or focus.  If the filmmakers don't know what the point of their film is, neither do viewers, whom are left confused and unsure of what to make of it all as the credits role.The story is an absolute mess and seems to be stitched together from numerous different scripts, each focusing on a different element; humor, thrills, sci-fi, and horror.  The result is a story where the pieces simply don't match up.  This puzzling blend of genre and plot elements along with multiple endings is no doubt to be blamed on the reportedly vehemently dissatisfied test audiences.  Frank Oz allegedly kept cutting, editing, and at times reshooting entire scenes up until a month or so before release.  It shows.The all star cast of the great Nicole Kidman, Matthew Broderick, Bette Midler, Glenn Close, Christopher Walken, and Faith Hill are tragically wasted on this bland, perplexing, and ultimately dissatisfying film.

reviewText: The 2004 movie version of Ira Levin's novel The Stepford Wives  reminds me of what Karl Marx said about history repeating itself: "the first time as tragedy, the second as farce."I want to be clear. This movie is the worst remake I have ever seen, and I'm including Jessica Lange's first movie, the 1976 version of King Kong. (I'm not blaming her for that, though - - it wasn't beauty killed THAT beast).The main problem here is that these new Stepford wives are in a big-budget picture instead of the modern equivalent of a B movie. By putting together "elements" like Nicole Kidman and Matthew Broderick it was always going to be a mainstream film that needed to earn tens if not hundreds of millions of dollars. So the filmmakers purposely made a comedy version which allowed them to have a happy ending that they thought a mass audience would like.We even find out at the end that men are soon to be the victims of the Stepford process too, poor babies. (I enjoyed Jon Lovitz and Bette Midler, but I could watch them do the same shtick on reruns of Seinfeld. In fact this movie sounded more than anything else like Ira Levin being channeled by the writers of Will and Grace.)The 1975 version directed by Bryan Forbes agitated both the audience who recognized Joanna's desperation and the audience who thought the movie was a vicious male backlash. Not everybody got it, but everybody was affected by it. In 2004 The Stepford Wives upsets no one.The are a few nods to Bryan Forbes's movie. We first see Mike (Christopher Walken), the apparent Stepford Svengali, dressed in black the way his forerunner Diz was when Joanna challenged him in her kitchen back in 1975. But Walken just plays his usual freak and doesn't unnerve the way the low-budget film and TV actor Patrick O'Neal did.This time the name Eberhardt belongs to Joanna - - her husband has his own last name. This shows how feminism changed over thirty years (if you can get anyone, man or woman, to use the F-word any more) - - unimportant things have changed for the better, but in important areas things have gone backwards.Just the fact that someone could think to tell this story as a comedy shows that the first Joanna didn't make it out of Stepford alive.How have things changed for men in thirty years in Stepford? When the Men's Association got together in 1975 their conversation was so inane that Joanna didn't understand how her husband Walter could stand to listen to it. In 2004 the husbands play with toy SUVs in their clubhouse (their big ones are parked outside) the way the upper-class idiots in P. G. Wodehouse's Drones Club played cricket with rolls.SPOILERS FROM HERE (AS IF YOU COULDN'T SEE THEM COMING):There's one moment of wit when Glenn Close (not surprisingly the real mistress in Stepford) tells everyone she's neither a person nor a machine - - "I'm a lady."The main difference between the two Stepfords is that in 1975 Diz and the husbands kill their wives. In an attempt at a scary scene, Nicole Kidman's Joanna Mark MMIV comes across a robotic simulacrum of herself lying on a slab. The robot's eyes jerk open to show only blackness - - what Katharine Ross saw in her double's face as it combed its long hair.So we think that this Joanna, like her predecessor, is going to be eliminated and replaced by a robot. But in the second-to-the-last scene Walter deactivates nanochips implanted in the brains of all the Stepford wives and they return to normal. So they weren't killed and replaced by robots. Why does Joanna have a spooky robot but the other Stepford wives don't?And it's too bad that in thirty years we needed to go back to stories where the husband decides if the wife lives or dies.When the members of the Men's Association reveal their secret to Walter (unlike the first movie, there's no hint that Walter brought Joanna to Stepford knowing what was going to happen to her - - cute Matthew Broderick wouldn't do THAT) they demonstrate their power by having one of the wife-robots dispense cash from her mouth like an ATM. We already know that money is the only important thing to Stepfordites and should be to us too (after all, the husbands are doing this because their wives make bigger salaries and are more successful than they are), but how do you get the cash into a human body?Movies like this remind me why, overall, I like B-movies better than big-budget films. There is hardly ever any human feeling in a movie with a big star in it. If we weren't Stepford Audiences, maybe we'd get better movies than this version of The Stepford Wives.

reviewText: I used to know a guy who put tons of bumper stickers on his car.  On one side were left-wing ones like VISUALIZE WORLD PEACE and ARMS ARE FOR HUGGING.  On the other side were conservative quips like ABORTION IS MURDER and I'M THE NRA AND I VOTE.  He did this to confuse anyone trying to figure out what he believed.This movie does the same thing.  In reading the prior reviews it is interesting to see how some interpret it as a left-wing PC film and others dismiss it as anti-female.  What it really is is incoherent.  Kidman's character, for example....is she a virtuous heroine or a sleezeball "Jerry Springer with breasts" who ruins lives for ratings?  Is Broderick a "real" man or a wimp?  And if this community is an idealized 1950s clone then why is it so accepting of gay people?The wives - they appear to be simultaneously robots and humans.  If the nano-chips are the only physical modification then what is the deal with the robot bodies?  And the ending - is Midler's opinion of men the real theme of the movie, or is it a parody poking fun at men-bashing ultra-feminists?One more question: if this is a comedy where were the funny moments?Maybe the producers were trying to be all things to all people.  Maybe it was a case of too many cooks spoiling the soup.  Or maybe the writers just suck at their jobs.  In any event, except for the fine acting skills of Nicole Kidman this film was a pointless waste of time.  My advice: skip it.  That's the only thing about this movie I'm sure of.

reviewText: This is a brilliant cast with a story line that fails to resonate the way it once did.  The "Stepford Wives" was once image-provoking short hand for the manifestation of conformity and the absence of control.  That idea still sells. In fact, it's interesting that The Manuchurian Candidate and this film appeared in such temporal proximity to one another.  For some reason The Manchurian Candidate can still prompt one to think about the prospect of manipulation at high levels.  That may quite possibly stem from the alleged influence of money in politics or other factors that seem to influence decision-making at the highest levels.  But Stepford Wives, well-acted as it was, is fun, but not fundamentally thought provoking.  Yet, there's a morale in it: the ability to manipulate the other sex lacks appeal as theory, even if it were feasible in practice.  Much like the orgy in Eyes Wide Shut, where the regimentation and ritualization of sex dampens its appeal, the ability to manipulate mechanistically a community of wives is a one-way ticket to dystopia.  Stil, if you can suspend belief long enough to enjoy it, it's a fine comedy.  As often happens, the key is to enter the experience with the right set of expectations.

reviewText: Full of promise but disjointed in writing and appearance, "The Stepford Wives" explores life in a suspiciously perfect suburban town. Nicole Kidman (terrific!) plays Joanna Eberhard, a corporate superwoman recently fired after a spectacular business failure. Husband Walter Kresby (Ha ha! funny name!), played by a sleepwalking Matthew Broderick, is her supportive, yet lonely and unhappy husband. They move to postcard-perfect Stepford, Connecticutt in order to put balance back into their lives and their marriage. But something is not right in paradise. Newly-arrived wives cringe at the porcelain perfection of the town's pretty little housewives. Yet their husbands seem to thrive in the forced atmosphere of male camaraderie, cigar smoking, barn dancing and generally wholesome fun. What is behind the disparity is at the core of the movie.Aside from turning a horror movie into a comedy, removing any element of peril, the Stepford writers don't try too hard to update the original. They lift the ambience, attitudes and assumptions of the 1960s and airdrop them into post-modern 2004. The movie does add a gay couple and a hippy Jewish couple (actually, played hilariously by Jon Lovitz and Bette Midler) which are the extent of the life in this tepid and lifeless movie. But in trying to pay homage to the original, they left some very loose strings. In the original, the human wives were killed and replaced by robots. In this most timid remake, the wives are merely electronically enhanced. Yet the witless writers try to have their remake cake and eat the original too. They retain the original's trademark horror scene -- where a wife comes face to face with her mechanical replacement -- even though the remake uses no robots. That's sloppy, dumb and insulting."The Stepford Wives" imperfectly transposes male-female power struggles from the 1960s to the 2000s. Thirty years ago, men were threatened by the very presence of women in traditionally male-oriented jobs. Replacing them with electronic love dolls satirized the era's male angst. Today, the film has us believe, men are threatened by uber-successful women. This weak translation hardly taps into the everyday experience of most men, who have adapted quite well to the reality of women in the workplace, notwithstanding the fulminations of certain talk-radio programs. The film also has us believe that men want their wives to be bouffant-haired hostesses sitting around baking cookies and making Christmas ornaments. The widespread disdain for Martha Stewart might have been a clue that this decade's angst lies elsewhere."Stepford Wives" is a bit of tasteless yet harmless entertainment, like a slice of leftover bundt cake in the fridge. Consider renting this frothy remake, if you must, but buy the dark, brooding original.

Ever since "Moulin Rouge" and "The Hours," people have been gushing about how glamorous and great Kidman is.  Perhaps I'm in the minority here, but if it weren't for Tom Cruise, we probably would have never heard of her.  Don't get me wrong, I thoroughly enjoyed her in "The Others," but none of her other movies have ever made me breathless or cry."The Stepford Wives" is no exception.  First of all, Kidman's character is presented as a total ice queen hellbent on destroying other people's lives on television to make a quick buck.  One of her victims gets crazy on his wife and some of her new boyfriends as a result of the show and the network cuts Kidman loose.  She has a breakdown and she and her loyal husband(Matthew Broderick) move to the beautiful little community of Stepford in order to recuperate.Right off the bat, Kidman starts to notice how the wives of this community are way too perfect.  They are all gorgeous, loyal to their husbands and children, and have hobbies like knitting and baking(except for Bette Midler and a gay man, who haven't been turned yet).  The men of the community hang out at a men's club on a hill in the town.  The men begin to court Broderick's character right away.  Kidman, Midler, and the gay guy start snooping around to see just what the heck is going on.From there, the story completely falls apart.  Midler and the gay guy(who's actually the funniest part of the movie) are turned into "perfect" spouses(or life partners).  Kidman catches on to the "horrible" acts happening in Stepford, but she might be too late to save even herself.The rest of the movie is bland and boring.  With the exception of the gay guy, the movie just isn't funny.  Glenn Close and Christopher Walken are the flagship couple of the perfect little community.  It is ashame that two fine actors as themselves are wasted in this trash.  John Lovett also appears in this flick as Midler's loser husband.  In all, there are some really good actors and actresses in this movie, but it's just horrible.  Faith Hill was splashed all over the country for being in this flick.  The result is that she is nothing but eye-candy.  Unfortunately, that's probably the only reason they put her in here(unless the producers were going for the pop-country audience).So, I hate to tear a movie apart like this, but I feel that I have to.  I've seen very few movies as dull or boring as this one.  The acting is bad, comedy is almost non-existent, and the ending is goofy.  Don't hop onto the Nicole Kidman bandwagon and waste your money on this.Not recommended.
summary: Overrated Actress In An Overrated Remake

reviewText: If you are going to remake "The Stepford Wives" then I agree that it has to be done as a black comedy instead of taking another stab at making a horror film with a touch of social satire.  After all, the cat is out of the bag as to why the "perfect" women of Stepford are the way that they are, so there is no reason for the script by Paul Rudnick ("Addams Family Values") to keep the characters in the dark when the audience already knows surprise.  So when Joanna Eberhart (Nicole Kidman) moves to the town of Stepford and her husband, Walter Kresby (Matthew Broderick) starts enjoying cigars and brandies at the Men's Association, we know most of what is coming, albeit with a series of twists appropriate to the new millennium.However, there is a fatal flaw to this updated version.  Granted, you have to take the science in "The Stepford Wives" with large measure of the willing suspension of disbelief, but for some reason that is beyond the understanding of mere mortals this film cannot decide what the secret science happens to be in this case.  We are thinking robots before the movie starts, we are thinking when some of the Stepford wives act like robots, and we are pretty much thinking robots right until a short education films provides a different explanation for the creation of the Stepford Wives.  Without giving away too much of a movie that presumes it has given a lot away in the first place, the robot science versus the non-robot science are incompatible.  When you watched the deleted scenes on the DVD this becomes even more obvious.  Apparently Rudnick and director Frank Oz got to a point where they had to choose which way to go and they tried to have it both wives.This is not to say that there are not some wonderful satirical skewers delivered verbal by Rudnick and visually by Oz.  Both AOL and Connecticut get knocked out by choice one-liners.  But the house of cards being constructed here just has too many severe structural problems.  For example, it seems that the wives of Stepford are not just women infected with first-stage feminism (Katharine Ross's Joanna in the original wanted to be a photographer, whereas Kidman's Joanna was a network programmer), but they are feminist amazons, who had been CEO's, judges, and brain surgeons.  As this Joanna admits, she had wanted to be a castrating, Manhattan career bitch dressed all in black ever since she was a little girl.  The complaint of the men in the Stepford Men's Association is that they were turned into women as they supported their wives, and is at that point that this movie went off the tracks for me.Riddle me this, boys and girls: If the women were all rich and successful, then THEY were the ones who had the money that BOUGHT the houses.  Even if, for the sake of argument, we say that all of these women have golden parachutes, what on earth would make them all decide to move to Stepford?  Once the husbands have their picture perfect wives, what will they do for money?  I am perfectly willing to admit I am over thinking this one, and I have proven in the past to put up with lots of nonsense in movies for the sake of narrative completeness, but since they messed by on the science part of the equation here they have used up their available credit for the rest of the film as well.Still, this new version of "The Stepford Wives" is worth checking out, whether you have seen the original or not.  I think you should see the original first, simply because you can appreciate some of the little twists that given particular scenes and characters.  Besides, the cast is not to be faulted for the script problems.  Kidman knows how to invest luminosity with a touch of lunacy, Broderick does a nice little twist on his good guy character, and you have Bette Midler, Glenn Close, and best of all Christopher Walken providing one of his patented performances, so we are not cheated on that score.  It is just that a script that shows this much wit should show the same sort of intelligence when it comes to the basic story premises as well.
summary: A return visit to the wives of Stepford as a black comedy

reviewText: It seems to me that if you are going to remake a film, there should be a good reason. Either it should be an improvement on the original or at least have something new to say. The remake of The Stepford Wives, directed by Frank Oz, does not fulfill either of these requirements. One problem is that the film cannot make up its mind whether it wants to be a lighthearted farce or a dark social satire and doesn't really work as either. Nicole Kidman is Joanna, a cynical producer of reality television shows (which are lampooned in an over-the-top manner). When she survives an assassination attempt but is fired from the network, she and her nerdy husband (Matthew Broderick) retreat to the idyllic Connecticut community of Stepford. I assume that most people know the basic premise, so I don't think it's much of a spoiler to mention that the wives of Stepford have been transformed into obedient robots to satisfy their husbands' every whim. Christopher Walken, as usual, has a sinister role as the head of the community.The overall mood of The Stepford Wives is light, with Bette Midler as her usual feisty self as another recent addition to Stepford who doesn't fit in. "Fitting in" as a Stepford wife means dressing and behaving like a caricature of a 1950s sitcom housewife. This is a central feature of the film that had a lot more impact in the original, if only because that was thirty years ago. The Stepford wives in this film are beyond parody --the way they dress, speak and focus on household chores is simply not believable. Even if we accept the premise of the film, if someone was going to program modern day housewives, they would at least make them more up to date in superficial ways.As the beginning of the film suggests (though not very well in my opinion), there is plenty to satirize about life today. Today's Stepford Wives would be latte-sipping, cell phone-toting soccer moms. But the film doesn't want to make fun of something real and contemporary --for fear of offending its intended audience? After the opening parody on reality TV, the film plays it safe and retreats back into the mythic 50s, which have already been parodied to death by other films. It is all too easy to make fun of what almost no one actually believes in anymore, and this undercuts any pretensions the film has to being serious social commentary. Of course, much of it is done in a light, slapstick mode, but this doesn't jibe with the heaviness of the basic theme. When it comes down to it, stealing peoples' identities and replacing them with a computer chip is not a light theme. There are even some basic holes in the technology premise of Stepford Wives, as some other reviews have pointed out. In most of the film, the wives are real women who have been implanted with a computer program, but in several scenes they are portrayed as actual robots. This is apparently something that was not reconciled in the final draft of the script. This is a fairly significant flaw in a story with a sci-fi premise, and indicative of the lack of thought that went into the film as a whole. Stick with the original. If you want something more up to date, the current television series Desperate Housewives is a much sharper and funnier satire on suburban housewives.

reviewText: This was an astounding misfire. It involves a perfect community (for men) where all the women cook, clean and pleasure the guys all the time. The film was scary and original when first released in 1975 (based on a novel by Ira Levin). The remake was a bomb with a $90 million budget but ended up making only $59 million domestically. With an A-list cast it could have been great. It turned an interesting premise that made a huge impact in 1975 into a comedy/sci-fi film. The Stepford Wives remake was campy on the day of release (in 2004). This film is so odd it doesn't know what to do with itself. It thinks it's a comedy at times and more dramatic at other times. The casting of Bette Midler and Jon Lovitz is the first clue that this isn't going to work. Roger Bart (Hostel 2) is very annoying. Christopher Walken is great but not used properly (his "global commercial" was horrible) leaving only Nicole Kidman and Matthew Broderick who did a fairly good job. The film doesn't take itself seriously nor does it expect you to do so. Ultimately, it just doesn't work on any level. Since the novel is fairly short we come to the end of the first hour expecting new material. Unfortunately, the final battle and ending don't work story-wise and completely change the tone of the novel. Nowhere is the memorable soundtrack, suspense and paranoia of the original. The production was filled with fights, re-shoots and challenges of all kinds. Apparently director Frank Oz also had problems when filming The Score. The Stepford Wives doesn't seem to connect with Amazon reviewers either who give it a lowly 3 star rating. reviewText: The new Stepford Wives is everything a remake should be. It takes the plot of the original film and updates it, but doesn't try to duplicate the film itself. This is a different movie althogether, played for laughs, and surprisingly, it works. The feminist message in the brilliant 1975 original is very dated and this film knows it and uses it to its advantage. It also takes a stab at everything today, from how absurd reality television is to the ridiculous concept of "the woman's place is in the home." It shows how little has actually changed since the original novel and film were released but updates the story to fit into modern times, and make it something today's audience can relate to.I was skeptical when I heard the creepy 1975 thriller was going to be remade as a comedy, but I was pleasantly surprised.  Talk of how bad this movie is hit the internet months ago, and because of all the negativity surrounding it, I didn't know what to expect,  but I guess the reshoots really helped because I enjoyed the film. The preview audience I saw it with also ate it up. This is perhaps the funniest comedy to come out all year and, along with Saved!, one of the most biting satires in recent memory.Nicole Kidman and Mathew Broderick are both quite good, but the real standouts are Bette Midler, Glenn Close, and Roger Bart as the gay Stepford Wive, a brilliant and neccessary edition. It was nice to have Christopher Walken in the mix as well. He can liven up even the worst film, which shows what a great actor he is,  very versatile. He fit in perfectly with the brilliant ensemble cast. Faith Hill fans will be somewhat disappointed though, since she doesn't have a very big part. It's actually little more than a cameo, but she looks amazing and acts well in the few scenes she's in. She really didn't get a chance to stretch her acting chops, but I look forward to seeing her in many more films to find out what she's really capable of.The Stepford Wives was surprisingly hilarious, colorful, and a pure joy to watch. The characters are wonderful and the dialogue sparkles. Only a gay man could write such clever and funny dialogue and it shows.  Better Midler has some terrific one-liners. Her pinecone comment, which I cannot mention here or this review won't even go up, was the icing on the cake. I couldn't breathe I was laughing so hard throughout.Hopefully people will give this film a chance. Much like Saved!, it deals with a very serious topic, but the tone throughout is light and fluffy. Many people will probably hate it, but that's the kind of controversy that makes a film fun. The only problem I had was what I think is a HUGE hole in the plot concerning the Stepford Wives and HOW their husbands change them. The ending just doesn't seem consistant with the beginning, but it's not a big deal, I just figured I'd mention it. Maybe I missed something, but I doubt it. Either way, the movie is so fun, most people probably won't notice. This is a light, fun summer film definitely worth checking out. I can't wait to see it again!

reviewText: A movie sequels, I understand. The public loved the original. It made a lot of money. The original producers retain the rights to the material and stand to make another fortune, etc.Remakes have always been problematic for me. Was the original somehow deficient? Can a new version be better? Is there a dearth of originality in the movie industry?"The Stepford Wives" is a remake of a fairly good horror thriller, which was released in 1975. Based on an okay novel by Ira Levin, it did very well at the boxoffice. Part of the reason it did so was that Levin penned the vastly superior novel "Rosemary's Baby", which was made into a truly classic movie in 1969. People were eager to see his next effort.The crux of the 1975 version was the revolt of men against the rise of feminism. The men in the movie were appalled that the women in their lives were becoming not just their equals, but their superiors. In the exclusive community of Stepford, Connecticut, hope was found. Someone found a way to turn these ambitious, dangerous women into docile playthings for the men.The plot of the new version, though heavily altered, still focuses on new residents, Joanna and Walter [Nicole Kidman and Matthew Broderick]. A high-powered NYC TV executive whose career has hit the skids, Joanna immediately notes how all the Stepford wives are so odd and robotic. Walter, ever envious of his wife's career, pretends not to notice.The remake tries to bridge the 30-year gap from the original by using satirical comedy rather than horror. For the first half of the movie, this works. In the second half, everything devolves into a nonsensical mess.As an example as to how `all over the map' this version is, there is a subplot involving a gay male couple. One guy lets his partner be turned into a "Stepford" wife. I've no doubt there is a message here, but what it is escapes me. How can a group of conservative men  accept a gay couple? If the object is to turn women into homemaking sex slaves, why turn a guy into this?The film sports three great actresses - Kidman, Glenn Close and Bette Midler. They are fun to watch, as always, but they are wasting their time here. Ironically, their talents are trashed in this effort, practically turning the stars themselves into "Stepford Wives".
summary: Okay comedy remake of an okay 1975 thriller

reviewText: When I heard that director Frank Oz called his cast back to do reshoots for Wives to "tighten up the story," I immediately said 'uh oh.' Let's be honest: hearing that is never a good thing, and after watching the movie I can tell you exactly where those reshoots occurred (but to no avail): the film's atrocious final act. Which is kind of a bummer, considering that the movie, though silly, is funny and light enough to keep clipping along for quite a while. Nicole Kidman seems to be having fun playing Joanna Eberhard, a fired TV-exec who moves with her husband (Matthew Broderick), to the town of Stepfod. I won't get into the specifics of the plot because (a) I only feel like writing two paragraphs and (b) I'm sure my readers have seen it or already know...so let's talk Bette Midler. Frumpy, hilarious, and scene-stealing for nearly half of the movie, she's a complete gem. I loved her over-the-top character, the great one-liners she had, and loved her so much that I could forget the fact that Matthew Broderick acts like he has a stick up his ass. In fact, Midler's gleefully raunchy Bobbie Markowitz is the key to this film; when she undergoes her 'transformation' it just all goes to pot.Though I haven't seen the original film, a source tells me that it ends on a fittingly creepy note that I would have enjoyed seeing this one end on as well. In Ira Levin's novel, there is a powerful statement about what society is doing to women as a whole, and this movie could have pulled off driving the point home. Nevermind that. Writer Paul Rudnick tacks on a final scene that is so pointless, so utterly awful, I had to fight to stay in my seat. Out come multiple plot twists, Brodericks' wooden husband as a hero, and an ending that I had feared would occur. This movie is so uneven, jumping from great comedy to flat melodrama (just plug your ears when Kidman and Broderick discuss their marriage) to social commentary and to action that I couldn't decide which one would actually work for it. And therein lies the paradox: Stepford should have been totally a comedy or totally a creepy social statement, because together they just don't work. GRADE: C-

reviewText: For those of you who are not familiar with Brini Maxwell, she is a fictional homemaker (played by Ben Sander) on the Style Network since 2003 that loves pastels, is always cheerful and acts like a flashback to the 1950's/1960's.  Though it is unlikely that Brini Maxwell was an inspiration for the fictional women in the 2004 remake of the 1975 classic sci-fi/thriller/mystery film "The Stepford Wives", there are several striking similarities.  At the beginning of the film, Joanna Eberhart (Nicole Kidman) is a network TV exec that loses her job over her controversial television shows.  In an attempt to salvage their marriage, her husband Walter Kresby (Matthew Broderick) purchases a new, computerized home in the quiet and wealthy Connecticut subdivision of Stepford.  There, they meet the couple that created Stepford: Mike Wellington (Christopher Walken) and his all-too-perfect wife Claire (Glenn Close).  Other recent arrivals in Stepford include Dave and Bobbie Markowitz (Jon Lovitz and Bette Midler) and the gay couple of Roger Bannister (Roger Bart) and Jerry Harmon (David Marshall Grant).  As Joanna, Bobbie and Roger attempt to adjust to life in Stepford, they can't help but notice the odd, always bubbly & cheerful personalities of the women who live there.  Everything about the people in Stepford just seems a little too perfect, which encourages the trio to do a bit of investigating; but all of them have already been tagged to become part of Stepford's all-too-perfect "Ozzie & Harriet" world.  However, not everything goes quite as planned.The world created in the 2004 "The Stepford Wives" by director Frank Oz and screenplay writer Paul Rudnick was just a little too surreal to make the film's characters particularly engaging.  The original story, written by Ira Levin, was not originally intended to be a comedy.  Therefore, attempting to combine its mystery/thriller aspects with humor that is often dry and predictable, as well as with personalities that are too reminiscent of the aforementioned Brini Maxwell, just doesn't blend into something smooth.  Instead, the result is a lightweight story with many bumps along the way that drag the film down a lot.  At least the last 10 to 15 minutes of the film are quite funny, interesting and entertaining.  Consequently, the highest rating that I can give to the 2004 version of "The Stepford Wives" is only 3 out of 5 stars. The whacked out ending with Broderick running around pushing buttons leads us to believe that the women are still human, but if that's the case, then how did a human become a walking ATM machine; why wasn't Bette Midler's hand fried when she put it on the stovetop; why was their a new "body" for Nicole when Matt's supposed to initiate her into her new Stepford wife role?  This lack of cohesiveness ultimately destroys the movie, and the ending is so over the top and ridiculous, one can only wonder what the screenwriter and director were trying to pull on its audience. reviewText: People were pretty bent out of shape about this movie when it came out.  It was a remake of the original (which is almost never as good), and they thought it was ridiculously cheesy.  There are some parts where they are trying to hard, no question, but I liked it.  It was far from the greatest movie ever made, to be sure, but I liked some of the comments they made here and there.Joanna (played brilliantly by the wonderful Nicole Kidman) is a high powered TV executive whose reality TV show went bust and cost her a dream job.  After recoving from her breakdown and her shock treatments, she and her family move to a delightful, chipper little suburb of Connecticut by name of Stepford.  While they settle in, Joanna befriends Bobbie, a liberal cynical writer, and a sassy flamboyant gay man (who provided the best comic relief of them all).  Something is not right in this fair town, as the other women are all perfect sex kitten bimbos who are all happy and busy and wonderful.  Their husbands, a bunch of drooling nerds who Joanna's husband Walter joins at the men's club, are strange and adored by their beautiful wives.  Slowly but surely, things begin to shift.  The formerly flamboyant gay boyfriend turns into a stiff, Brooks Brothers suit wearing Repulican content to stand by his man's side as a more passive partner.  Bobbie, once Joanne's best ally, suddenly turns into a June Cleaver who is content to make the world as perfect as the other wives do.  Joanne panics.Once they inevitably take Joanne into their clutches at the men's club, she too becomes a Stepford wife.  But, here is where the movie takes a dive from the original.  They overthrow the mastermind of Mike (CHristopher Walkin) and free the other wives from the clutches of Stepfordization.  Only to find out that Glenn Close was the real mastermind of the plot.  And everyone lives happily ever after.Some of the comments made in this movie ring just as true today as they did 30 some years ago, but others are more modern things and full of the same contraditions we deal with today.  Men in general, despite how far we've come, want someone lesser than they are - education, career, job, and even the more personal things like attractiveness, confidence, personality, intelligence, and dare I say it height.  Power is sexy, but men are intimidated by a powerful woman.  I look back on all my old boyfriends, with a few notable exceptions they were all intimidated by me because I was braver, smarter, a harder worker, and simply better than they were.  And yet, there is also a strange want that maybe all of us have for a simplier time, where our roles were more clear and more defined.  But now, it's too crazy.  More than half of the married women I know are the bread winners in their households, and they have to balance career and family out of necessity rather than choice.  Now it's become a sign of prosperity if the woman doesn't have to work.  Isn't it ironic?  There wasn't all this talk about family values and quality time, it just was the way it was.  Women didn't have to be the aggressors, and men didn't have to be the nurturers.  Maybe it was a little easier back then, but it's forever changed.

reviewText: What were people expecting, I wonder, when this remake was announced?With Frank Oz at the helm, Glenn Close and Bette Midler providing the comic relief and Christopher Walken in the role of the Stepford Patriarch, could this movie ever have turned out as anything other than high camp?No, and you'd be stupid to even try to compare it to the excellent original.In and of itself, however, 'The Stepford Wives' is a solid, well-made sort of comedy that won't win any awards, won't change the face of film making as we know it, and certainly won't stay with people for very long. But what it does, it does well - gentle undemanding comedy with broadly-drawn characters and some really rather beautiful set-pieces to look at mean that, even though it's as predictable as Martha Stewart in a Kitchen, at least it's a very entertaining sort of movie.Nicole Kidman plays Joanna Eberhart, a high-powered career minded TV executive, who, after losing her job and having a subsequent breakdown, is ferried by 'loving' husband Walter (Matthew Broderick) to the town of Stepford, Connecticut, where she is aghast at the seeming chauvanistic conformity of the majority of the townswomen. Allying herself to her more normal contemporaries Bobbie Markowitz (Bette Midler) and Roger Bannister (Roger Bart), the trio begins to unravel something of the mystery behind a community headed by the mysterious Mike (Christopher Walken) and his ueber-perfect wife Claire Wellington (Glenn Close).Close turns in a really rather terrific performance here, full of high falsetto and trembling over-enunciation. As with the rest of the Stepfords, the all-important 'sinister' aspect is missing here, but in the final scenes of the movie she really shines, garnering more laughs with her closing speech than the rest ofthe cast does throughout the movie. Kidman and Midler are in preschool here, they deliver their lines and act their emotions with all the energy of a tired basset hound, but they do it so well you don't really notice the lack of creativity in the roles. Roger Bart turns in a formulaic, if likeable enough, performance as Stepford's First Gay 'Wife', and the chemistry between the cast, while not really important, is enough to be believable.The movie is beautifully shot, with major attention to detail in all of the Suburban settings - Oz and his team have gone to great lengths to provide a really rather sumptuous vision of the Gated Community of Stepford, and this is where the picture shines - sure, the dialogue may be mundane and the plot predictable, but the visuals are so pretty and well-suited to the piece that it's hard not to like the movie more. The Book Club, Day Spa and Town Picnic scenes are really rather good, and lend a real sense of professional gloss to this otherwise ordinary movie.And that's about it, really. Hollow, unsurprising and not very creative, 'The Stepford Wives' is also solid, well-made and, if you take it as a separate movie to the original, quite enjoyable.Recommended.

reviewText: This remake of the 1975 blockbuster (itself based on Ira Levin's book) updates the plot with current events, and modern plot twists.  Cynics can no longer write off this title as a time-sensitive fad, and must instead acknowledge its continued urgency to American cultural and political life.  Because the fashions and home decorations are generally updated for today's audiences, it is easier for my and future generations to focus upon the storyline's relevance to our own lives.After she is fired from her network executive position and then suffers a nervous breakdown, Joanna Eberhard (Nicole Kidman)  and her family move to the idyllic town of Stepford Connecticut. Priding herself on independence and strength, Joanna is quickly horrified to learn that most of the town's female residents are unabashed throwbacks to the idealized version of the 1950s, and Mike Wellington (Christopher Walken) presides over a quasi-secret men's club while wife Claire exherts a parallel pull over most female residents. Joanna quickly bonds with fellow outcast Bobbie Markowitz (Bette Middler), a writer who has remained cynical about the hamlet AND retained liberation despite her own long-term Stepford residence.Contrasting with the earlier film (which arrived shortly after the stonewall rebellion and before GLBT Americans came out in today's numbers), this version has an openly gay couple in the town---Roger Banister (Roger Bart) and Jerry Harmon (David Marshall Grant) . The people of Stepford pride themselves on being robo-Republicans but they are also happy to be just open-minded enough to publicly acknowledge the long-term relationship (hardly a benign issue with same-sex marriage making headlines around the country). Alas, he too is headed for dire consequences---because he becomes one of the very few Log Cabin Republicans after his own transformation.Joanna's husband Walter Kresby (Matthew Broderick) appears visibly reluctant in his own right to claim the numerous privileges Stepford confers upon him specifically because of sex.  He is obviously charmed by the town, but eventually realizes that he had specifically fallen in love with Joanna because she was an independent person who could NEVER be the "all American homemaker".Well-placed jabs at infamous rightwing women activists (such as Phyllis Schafly and Beverly Lahaye) abound when the town finally wakes up and realizes who was REALLY responsible for programming all of the women into being airheads.  Not all women are victims of subordination because other women made a very public name for themselves ensuring that their gender either remains or returns to inequality. When the plan is explained, this same person becomes instantly transformed from the idealized norm to a desperate and psychotic shellYet, if men are really unwitting accomplices in this same caper, this critical scripting update also suggests they can be, should be, and are important partners in women's equality.  Women's liberation ultimately makes both genders happy and well-rounded members of society.  Conversely, women's restriction also prevents men from enjoying life.
summary: This movie has remained relevant for my generation

reviewText: *1/2For its 21 Century movie incarnation, Ira Levin's classic feminist thriller "The Stepford Wives" has been re-imagined as a feel-good, slapstick comedy - a shift in tone that is, to put it mildly, a complete disaster for this story.  Bryan Forbes' wonderful 1975 movie version (starring Katherine Ross) included many comic scenes as well, but there the humor was pointed and dark, and provided a perfect counterpoint to the sinister thriller elements at the story`s core.  In this "new and improved," ever-so-sunny edition of the Levin work, written by Paul Rudnick and directed by Frank Oz, the whole thing is played for laughs from the get-go, instantly robbing the story of its edge and diluting its delicious social commentary about a society in which women have literally become mindless robots responding to the commands of their misogynist husbands.  All we're left with, in the end, is a really bad, over-the-top comedy that wastes the talents of Nicole Kidman, Matthew Broderick, Glenn Close, Christopher Walken and Bette Midler and that tarnishes the memory of a good movie into the bargain.A pixie-haired Kidman plays Joanna Eberhart, a driven TV network executive who is fired when one of the man-hating programs she produces goes terribly awry.  Determined to become a more supportive wife and engaged mother, she allows her husband to cart the family off to a gated, crime-free, all-white, politically conservative (though, somehow, a gay couple is allowed to slip through) community in Connecticut known as Stepford, a 1950's throwback where all the wives are perfect little Susy Homemakers who dress in poofy, pastel-colored gingham dresses, maintain spotlessly clean and flawlessly decorated homes, smile constantly, and dutifully cater to each and every one of their husbands' whims and wishes.  Even though Joanna intends to make every effort to become the ideal wife that her understanding husband wants her to be, she soon begins to suspect that there may be a dark secret lurking beneath the impossibly perky dispositions of all the women in town.Although the plot here is virtually the same as it was in the 1975 film, this "Stepford Wives" has taken the entirely wrong approach to the Levin material.  Part of what made the earlier version so much fun was that we learned right along with Ross what was actually taking place in the town.  Her slow awakening to the truth was what provided the suspense so essential to making the tale frightening and compelling.  Here, however, the women are such ridiculous space cadets from the outset that any newcomer would have to be a complete idiot not to figure it all out the moment she hit town.  Moreover, as a comedy, the film falls miserably flat, going for the cheap and easy laugh at every opportunity.  And, of course, the movie lacks the courage to carry through with the earlier film's downbeat, defeatist ending, opting instead for an upbeat and "clever" surprise-twist finale that shows just how far filmmaking has fallen over the past 30 years.  (It also makes absolutely no sense in light of the scene where Midler puts her hand directly into the flame of a gas stove and suffers no burn - but then who expects coherence and consistency from a film this badly written and thought out?).  The irony is that the first version, while retaining the thriller elements of the story, was far more humorous and far more effective as a satire than this limp little remake could ever possibly hope to be.Perhaps, after this movie and "Bewitched," Ms. Kidman should avoid appearing in any more comedies - or at least any more comedies based on decades-old cultural artifacts - for the foreseeable future.This dreadful, ill-fated version of "The Stepford Wives" leaves us with just one basic question: if you're not going to do a remake properly, why do it at all?

reviewText: The real star of "The Stepford Wives" isn't Nicole Kidman or Matthew Broderick or Christopher Walken but writer Paul Rudnick, who updates Ira Levin's novel into a gabby zingfest, light on the gender war, syrup heavy pop culture and fashion gags, diva material and colorful, loud stereotypes. That's not to say the movie isn't funny - it often is. But did we need a stupidly lighthearted "Stepford Wives" remake? Absence of consequence is better left to "Dodgeball" or "Bad Santa." More serious issues - female empowerment, emasculation, the pressure on women to be thin, fun, successful and nuturing all in the next multitasked 20 minutes - are at hand today than they were 30 years ago. Rudnick, who penned the very funny "In & Out" for Kevin Kline years ago, is not up for a sharpened, caustic, honest take.Joanna Eberhard (Kidman) is a Lady MacBeth television exec bent on building her programming around reality shows that pits men and women against each other. When the participant of one of the shows ("I Can Do Better!") loses it in public, Joanna's out of the network - and so is her husband, Walter (Broderick), who worked under Joanna. The ice queen has nervous breakdown and Walter takes the gang (including practically non-existant children) to Stepford, Connecticut, where the women are extremely - off. The golden-haired Mike (Walken) runs the town with a lizard's charm from the Men's Club atop the hill, and his wife, Claire (Glenn Close), is the local welcome wagon. Joanna finds only two kindred souls in the town: Jewish writer Bobbie (Bette Midler) and gay architect Roger (Roger Bart), who supplies most of the movie's best laughs as Rudnick's alter-ego, presumably.Kidman is better suited for comedy than she would seem; like her ex-husband, Tom Cruise - whom she seems the channel at times here - Kidman is best when given a boatload of gestures to take on, and she plays the terminally cynical Joanna with energy and pluck. She, Midler and Bart find an easy chemistry, while Close inhabits her tricky, "Sunset Boulevard" role with zeal. Rudnick has little success with the alpha male roles, however, and Broderick and Walken have rarely seemed so pasty. Broderick has subversion hard-wired into his acting. To render him obsolete says something.It's Rudnick's inabilty to erect two balanced sides of the gender debate that accounts for the film's weakness: It is a relentlessly liberal movie, with a twist on the Walken/Close relationship near the end meant to even the score slightly. It treats children as if they don't exist. Rudnick and director Frank Oz never quite figures out if the women are controlled by robots or microchips, and the movie treats its "secret" as if it needs to be closely held onto until the final reel."The Stepford Wives" has no real mystery. It could have at least been intellectually provocative.
summary: A cotton candy take on the gender debate.

reviewText: Bryan Forbes 1975 film of Ira Levin's novel is not one of the great science fiction movies but it's a fun little movie that, compared to this dreadful remake, looks like a towering masterpiece. In Forbes' film our heroine moves to the sleepy town of Stepford where everything seems just wonderful at first, only for a sense of mystery and dread to build up slowly as it gradually becomes clear that something is not quite right about the town's women. Oz throws that away by having the weirdness of the womenfolk grotesquely in our faces from the very start. Then in the Forbes original, once Joanna has figured out what is afoot, the film becomes a thriller as she tries desperately to escape sharing the fate of the town's other women. This too Oz throws away. There is no desperate pursuit. Kidman basically just quietly goes and places herself in the hands of the baddies. Having amputated all the mystery and suspense from the movie, Oz then tries to compensate by inserting some very lame humour with feeble comic turns from Bette Midler and Roger Bart as the other "wives" new to town. None of the other performances are much good either. Kidman is far from her best. Walken does his familiar sinister routine on autopilot and Glen Close delivers what must be one of the worst performances in the history of the cinema. By the time I got to the reprise of the supermarket sequence that was the end of the original movie I was hugely relieved as I was desperate for this dismal and tedious movie to end. No such luck, the movie didn't end there and there was another 20 minutes to go, comprising a truly asinine not to say incoherent new ending. At a time when there are a great many bad remakes of good movies getting made this has to be one of the very worst.
