reviewText: I winced when I heard that they were re-making the excellent Stepford Wives but going for laughs. Not that it would have been impossible to pull that off, but I had a feeling that the result could be something like this.The cutting social commentary that worked so well in the original movie (released in a different time period) is just lost here, mainly due to the naive and predictable screenplay. The idea of these Perfect Couples living in a bleak, Martha Stewart/Betty Crocker techno wasteland could have been the basis for a highly entertaining movie, and there are flashes of that here and there, but on the whole, this juggernaut just falls flat.One of the few updates that make some kind of sense is the way that the Masculine/Butch member of the gay couple is completely accepted by the other 'husbands' - the whole thing being based on role playing.This is an amazing cast, but they are so under-utilized that it is positively sad. John Lovitz absolutely shines with the few lines and situations he is given, but what a waste of a superb actor. Ditto for most of the cast.It's not unwatchable by any means, but it was certainly a great disappointment, and for me, the fault lies squarely with the script itself.

reviewText: This is a 30 years in the making rework of a mid 70's quirky and satirical original by the same name.  While no great fan of the first film, it was something new at the time, and hit with a lot more subtle impact than this shamefully bad remake.  The original also seemed to touch not only a comedic nerve but a socially conscious one, whereas this only scratches the surface.The main problem with this version are not the stars.  Nicole Kidman, Matthew Broderick, Christopher Walken, Bette Midler and others are all accomplished (elsewhere) and the editing, pace, music, and basic direction seem fine.  Technically, there are no major problems, and there is great costuming and set production. The big fault here is the script (writing), which is dull and tiresome as well as confusing and non-credible (even for a fantasy, sci-fi comedy).  And while the original seemed subtle and predictive, this seems out of topical place.  That is, this version seems to be unbelievably lacking in social comment of today's times.  Instead, the movie constantly uses symbols and icons from the mid 70's, which seems lazy when trying to remake something taking place 30 years later.For instance, Nicole Kidman's character is not believable in the beginning.  It is too over the top.  Here is where a more subtle approach would've worked wonders.  Matthew Broderick is cast as usual as the innocent, boy next door, quirky female hero, but we are supposed to believe he has had something going with Kidman's media corporate bitch from hell.  From the start then, as these two head off to a non-Manhattan, more peaceful and "organic" existence in Connecticut (where else?  Vermont perhaps?  Oregon?), the viewer already does not accept their characters as real, which eventually ruins everything else that follows.The key here is the concept of "subtle."  This version has none.  Instead of trying to dream up a modern day version of the days gone by "suburb bliss" of the 70's, this one opts instead for one back in the 50's.  While some may argue this was a general flaw in the original as well, in this one, we are now talking about 30 plus about 20 years, or more, and yet hip modern day hipsters like Kidman and Broderick can't see something wrong with the Stepford community they join?  It takes a whole movie for them to finally realize when they entered Stepford, they entered the Twilight Zone?While there are some semi-funny ideas here, but no real laughs, while the leads are all appealing, there are times when the viewer has to ask, when is this mess going to end?  And more importantly, when are the characters going to react to what they are experience the way actual "normal" not robotic folks might?Unfortunately, that only comes after many throw away scenes and ideas, all of which should've remained on the editing floor.  This seems like the worst of Hollywood Deal-Making 101.  Grab an old script or idea, rework it sprinkling a lot of celebrities, pay no real attention to the writing, include a lot of SHOULD'VE been deleted scenes and mix all together to make a quick buck for all, and you've got this.  A real waste of time for those who actually paid to see this in a theater, a decent enough actor wage, and a hope residuals (after net points) will be enough for all of those involved to make more crap like this in the future.If at all possible, rent before you buy.  Unless you might enjoy replaying this over and over again just to see how "they" make quick possible short term moneymakers out in Hollyweird these days.  But where's the fun in that?One topical note of interest, as the husbands and wives in the community of Stepford have the ability to do a lot with remote controls, it is gratifying at least that you the viewer have the opportunity to fast forward through this forgettable by the numbers sludge if you are misfortunate enough to having bought this without watching it first.Nicole and Matthew have and hopefully will see much better days.  Christopher Walken seems to be playing his Saturday Night Live "Continental Man" character.  Bette Midler, is wasted here.  This is a badly written script, that's all.  The original is much better, as it deals with its time period in a realistic manner.  This version adds a lot of high tech, but none of the characters are ever believable in the slightest.This movie should've been fun.  Instead, it winds up challenging the viewer to ever increasingly frustrating attempts at suspending belief to a point where any humor found in believable events is quickly dispatched, and is never heard from again, throughout.A real disappointment.  This could've been a great idea, if updated correctly.  Instead, it is the kind of movie where one is constantly asking "WTF" and so by the end, delivers nothing but the same, ultimately a real unpleasant experience.  Who would want to actually buy this, and watch it again, must in themselves I think, be part Borg...
summary: An unnecessarily confusing overblown, temporal mess..

We rather prefer to laugh at her when every gesture and word misses the mark far wide, done with irritatingly exaggerated manners which are no fun to see.Other supports are no good either, perhaps with the exception of Robert Bart as her friend in town. reviewText: This remake of a 1975 horror film is actually much more of a comedy but it carries tremendous punch directed at the heart of all the so called "moral values" of wealthy American families.Joanna (Nicole Kidman) begins this film as a real power hungry modern woman who runs her own network. Her husband (Matthew Broderick) seems happy to just surf behind her enormous wake while their children have everything but a real family to relate to. Upon losing her career, Joanna hits rock bottom and her husband sees a way to move the whole family to Connecticut in order to re-group and get happy. Meet Stepford, a charming and affluent town of plastic wealth where everything is just as perfect as can be and oh so morally correct......American suburbia explained. The town is filled with fixed smiles, happy but nerdy husbands, lots of lace and pastels and not a hair out of place, except for the husbands with comb-overs that is. From the outside such perfection is enticing but finally a film dares to show the reality of being a modern woman at the mercy of the American dream.....the idea fails but this movie soars!This film is directed by Frank Oz and he has done a really beautiful job with the scenes and coloring of this project. The funniest scenes are also the most heartbreaking exposing the realities of life behind all those perfect houses in the suburbs. Nicole Kidman is really good as the strong willed yet vulnerable Joanna. Broderick is the perfect nerdy but loyal husband with a desire for more control. Glenn Close is excellent as the main Stepford wife and her husband is played eerily by Christopher Walken. But by far the best couple in this film is Bette Midler and Jon Lovitz as the town's Jewish couple so far from perfect that they become infectiously endearing to anyone who can relate to reality.This movie leaves many socio-political stones upturned and vulnerable, mainly the idea that women must be extraordinarily beautiful, concentration camp thin yet extremely  well-endowed, proficient at baking a perfect cake, a fiend for boring sex and capable of being placed on mute by a remote or through a controlling man. Sadly I see these women everyday in the nearest grocery store with plastic smiles and botoked cheeks. Unlike the original, this film suggests that the blame lies in a nerdy husband's fear of being overshadowed by a powerful wife with her own opinions. If they can have remotes why can't we? Beware of the mask that society has placed on women and always be willing to control the remote yourself or you might end up in Stepford!

reviewText: Based on the book by Ira Levin, and the original 1975 film THE STEPFORD WIVES stars Nicole Kidman, Bette Midler, Glen Close, Matthew Broderick and Christopher Walken. All fine actors and actresses. But unfortunately none of them could save this film. And it's a shame too because this could of been a great remake considering it's A-List cast.I don't think I really have to go too much into the plot since I'm sure most people, even ones who haven't seen any of the various films or even read the book, would know already. So I'll just give it to you in a nutshell. Basically Nicole Kidman's character Joanna moves from the city with her family to the suburban gated community of Stepford, Connecticut. Everything is perfect. Perfect houses, perfect lawns, and perfect wives. But there is something eerily strange about the women of Stepford and soon Joanna finds out the disturbing truth about Stepford.Now, the original film was fantastic. It was full of suspense and enough creepiness to make your skin crawl. Even the ending, as dark as it may be, was something that was talked about and still is. So it's obvious to say that THE STEPFORD WIVES (1975) was going more into the direction of horror. The director of the remake, Frank Oz, decided to flip that and turn it into more of a comedy which sounds great because the film could be interpreted either way. But for some reason something went wrong and the resulting film has suffered terribly for it. Also, (Spoiler warning: although who really cares) the plot of whether the wives were killed and replaced with robots or brainwashed is so muddled that by the end of the film you find yourself confused. "If they weren't robots then why the sparks?" or "How did her breasts enlarge if all she had were a few chips in her head?" Yes the plot is a complete mess and I can't help but feel very sorry for the people involved because they turned something that could of been great with the advanced technology into something that wasn't.

reviewText: Sometimes, while watching a film that has great potential, it is difficult to understand or believe some of the inexplicable choices that film-makers decide upon.  In "The Stepford Wives", a great kernel of a story is turned into almost a complete and utter farce that could have been oh so much better.For a basic plot summary, "Stepford Wives" tells the story of Joanna Eberhart (Nicole Kidman), an extremely driven career women who suffers a nervous breakdown.  Husband Walter (Matthew Broderick) decides to move her and the family to the gated community of Stepford, managed by Mike Wellington (Christopher Walken).  In Stepford, however, Joanna and newfound friend Bobbie (Bette Midler) try to unravel the mystery behind the "always-smiling, just-a-little-too-perfect" Stepford wives and their odd husbands.I would give a spoiler alert here (and it still stands if you know absolute nothing about this movie), but the trailers and film itself do a pretty good job ruining that department.  To be blunt, it is so obvious that the Stepford wives are robots (based on a few incredibly stupid scenes and some really bad special effects) that it pretty much kills the ending.  It's almost like director Frank Oz was trying to mock the original film instead of crafting the taut masterpiece that could have been.And that truly is what is so sad about "The Stepford Wives".  The social concepts behind the film are very, very interesting for both men and women to think about, but this effort makes a mockery for them.  It plays serious issues for sight gags and farcical humor.  Heck, a movie like this would have worked better even as horror or suspense, but the comedy sinks it like an anchor.Basically, the only reason I can give the movie even two stars is because that "kernel of story" is interesting.  My exact rating would be about 1.5 stars, because I can't remember the last time I saw a movie that "screwed it up" this bad in the story-interpretation department.
